newsitem.title: USA: Dade County, Fla., mayor plans New York City visit.
newsitem.headline: Dade County, Fla., mayor plans New York City visit.

text.p: The mayor of Florida's Dade County and an entourage of finance, tourism and economic development officials have scheduled a visit to New York City next week to discuss the impact of Miami's financial woes on the county.
Dade Mayor Alex Penelas has insisted repeatedly that investors know the difference between the city and county been affected by Miami's budget deficit.
Penelas has also encouraged tourists to keep visiting, pointing that the airport and seaport are run by the county, not the city, and that Miami is only a small part of the metropolitan area.

To make sure that message gets across, a public relations firm hired by the Greater Miami Convention and Visitors Bureau is hosting a luncheon on January 29 "to set the record straight" for the New York media.
Penelas has also scheduled interviews with reporters from a multitude of financial and tourism publications and news services, including Reuters.

Penelas will be accompanied by Assistant County Manager David morris, who oversees Dade bond issues; finance director Rachel Baum; Bond Administrator Lydia Monzon-Aguirre: Commissionier Jimmy Morales, who chairs the county's finance and trust fund committee; and other officials from the visitors' bureau and the Beacon Council economic development group.
The visitors' bureau and Beacon Council are paying for the trip.
Miami, which is Dade's county seat, is struggling to close a $68 million deficit in its budget for the year that began Oct.1, and has been placed under the watch of a state-appointed oversight board.
But the city is only one of 29 municipalities that make up the metropolitan Miami area.
